communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Mayorkas ICE Death Emails
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Part A. S1 Deaths In ICE Custody Emails Meta-Data (or, alternatively, the Emails themselves)
A metadata list of all emails sent or received by DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas since February 2021, containing one or more of the following words or phrases: 
(1) “Death in custody”; (2) “In-Custody Death”; (3) “Detainee Death”; (4) “Inmate Death”; (5) “prisoner death” or (6) “ICE Directive 11003.5”. 
Please provide metadata showing: date sent, sender, attachments, file size, recipients (CC & BCC), and subject line.
If the agency’s position is that the existing meta-data necessary to provide this list is not a pre-existing agency record, we will instead accept each and every non-duplicative responsive email.

Part B. S1 ICE Custody Death Calendar Entries 
A list of all calendar entries for Sec. Mayorkas since February 2022 reflecting any meeting  the Secretary or a DHS designee was invited to or attended about ICE in-custody deaths, as reflected by the time of the meeting or any text accompanying the calendar invite. 

Part C. S1 Names of the 9 In-Custody Deaths on His Watch Meta-Data (or, alternatively, the Emails themselves)
All emails sent or received by DHS Secretary Mayorkas since February 2, 2021, referencing any of the following 9 individuals who have passed away in or shortly after being released from ICE custody since the Secretary’s confirmation: 

(1) Jesse Jermone Dean Jr.	The Bahamas	3/21/1962	2/5/2021	58	Calhoun County Jail
Battle Creek, Michigan (Calhoun Co. Michigan) 

(2) Diego Fernando Gallego-Agudelo	Colombia		3/15/2021	45	Port Isabel Detention Center, Los Fresnos, TX (Ahtna)

(3) Elba Maria Centeno Briones	Nicaragua	3/23/84	8/3/2021	37	El Valle Valley Detention Facility, Harlingen, TX (MTC) 

(4) Pablo Sanchez-Gotopo	Venezuela 	6/3/1981	10/1/2021	40	Adams County Detention Center, Natchez, Mississippi (CoreCivic) 

(5) Benjamin Gonzalez-Soto	Mexico	11/24/1985	7/8/2022	36	Florence SPC, & Central AZ Correctional Complex, Florence, Arizona (CoreCivic) 

(6) Kesley Vial	Brazil	8/29/98	8/24/2022	23	Torrance County Detention Center, Estancia, New Mexico (CoreCivic) 

(7) Melvin Calero	Nicaragua	9/29/83	10/13/2022	39	Aurora ICE Processing Center, Denver, Colorado (GEO) 

(8) Cristian Dimitriscu	Romania		3/7/2023			Otay Mesa Detention Center, Otay Mesa, California (CoreCivic) 

(9) Salvador Vargas	Mexico		4/4/2023	61 Stewart Detention Center, Lumpkin, Georgia (CoreCivic) 

There appear to be no meaningful consequences for a federal contractor that allows a preventable death in ICE custody. Retraining, a contract penalty amounting to just 20% of a single month’s invoice, or multiple contract penalties amounting to only $700k for two deaths, are the only measurable penalties ICE has publicly admitted to levying against contractors whose violation of their contracts take lives. ICE does not announce these penalties, or the findings supporting them, publicly. Perhaps they do not even share them with the Secretary of Homeland Security. We’d like to know if he’s asked. 

Secretary Mayorkas committed on camera to operating ICE detention facilities in a safe and humane manner. To this end, he has also committed to reviewing performance of facilities and cancelling contracts that fail to ensure humans are safe and cared for in accordance with federal requirements. Yet the facilities listed above, which are sites of repeat findings of violations, and repeat deaths, are all


Expedited Processing Request
Pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e), we hereby request expedited processing of this request, and certify under penalty of perjury that the following is true and correct to the best of our knowledge and understanding: 
Deaths in ICE custody have been the subject of widespread and exceptional media interest both historically and today. The very first in-custody ICE death listed above was found by DHS-OIG to have been preventable, and the result of medical neglect by ICE-contracted facility staff. See, https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2023-02/OIG-23-12-Feb23.pdf (“Our contracted medical team reviewed the other four deaths in ICE detention in FY 2021 and found one individual was not provided timely or appropriate care by medical staff at the Calhoun County Jail in Battle Creek, Michigan.”). Despite the OIG’s findings that Calhoun County and its medical contractor, the now-bankrupt Corizon (see https://www.alreporter.com/2023/02/17/corizon-prison-healthcare-provider-declares-bankruptcy-yescare-apparently-replaces-ceo/), failed to render timely or appropriate medical care to Jessie Dean before his death, ICE continues to contract with the County for the imprisonment of non-citizens, further endangering the lives of people locked inside. 

As ICE is about to rapidly expand its average daily population with the end of Title 42, our community is deeply concerned that DHS is unprepared to care for those it locks up. Expedited access to these records will help dispel or confirm these concerns, and position our network to take the appropriate actions necessary to prevent preventable deaths where the government refuses to do so. 

#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative 
Al Otro Lado

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

title: Personnel Records and Records Related to Body Scanners and Advanced Imaging Technologies

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Personnel Records and Records Related to Body Scanners and Advanced Imaging Technologies
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Freedom of Information Act Officer
Transportation Security Administration
601 South 12th Street
Arlington, VA 20598

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am writing to submit a limited Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request seeking records related to two areas of interest within the Transportation Security Administration (TSA): personnel records of TSA employees and records related to the TSA's use of body scanners and other advanced imaging technologies for the period of the last two years (2021-2023).

Firstly, I request any and all training programs and materials provided to TSA agents in the last two years, including any materials related to cultural competency or implicit bias training. Additionally, I would like to obtain any disciplinary actions taken against TSA agents, including any records related to employee misconduct, violations of TSA policies and procedures, or complaints filed against TSA agents. Lastly, I request internal investigations of TSA employees in the last two years, including any records related to allegations of abuse, harassment, or discrimination by TSA agents.

These records will help to provide transparency and accountability for the TSA's actions in maintaining high standards of conduct among its personnel. In support of this request, I would like to cite several court cases, including EPIC v. DHS, 615 F.3d 519 (D.C. Cir. 2010), where the court held that the TSA must release documents related to the effectiveness and privacy impact of body scanners used at airports. The court found that the public interest in transparency and accountability outweighed any privacy concerns related to the release of these records. Additionally, in NARA v. Favish, 541 U.S. 157 (2004), the Supreme Court held that FOIA requires the disclosure of records that could reasonably be interpreted as indicating an agency's ability or willingness to protect the privacy of individuals.

Secondly, I request any training materials and manuals provided to TSA agents on the use of body scanners and other advanced imaging technologies in the last two years. Furthermore, I request technical specifications for the scanners and technologies used by TSA agents. Additionally, I would like to obtain any reports or studies conducted by the TSA or other organizations related to the effectiveness and safety of these technologies in the last two years. Lastly, I request any records related to complaints or incidents related to the use of these technologies in the last two years, including any reports of malfunctions, false positives, or privacy concerns.

These records will help to ensure the effective and safe use of advanced imaging technologies and provide insights into any privacy concerns associated with their use. In support of this request, I would like to cite the case of Katz v. United States, 389 U.S. 347 (1967), where the court held that the Fourth Amendment protects individuals from unreasonable searches and seizures and that a warrant is required to conduct a search, absent some exception.

FOIA requires agencies to disclose records unless they are exempt from disclosure under one of nine exemptions listed in the statute. If you determine that any of the requested records are exempt from disclosure, I request that you provide a written explanation of the exemption and the specific reasons why it applies.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: NSA Quantum Computing Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Dear FOIA Officer,

I am writing to request records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) from the National Security Agency (NSA) regarding the NSA's activities related to quantum computing. Specifically, I request the following:

All reports, analyses, and briefings that discuss or analyze the use of quantum computing by the NSA or its contractors for intelligence, encryption, or other purposes.

All contracts, grants, and other agreements between the NSA and any other entities, including private companies and academic institutions, related to research or development of quantum computing technology.

All correspondence, including emails, memos, and letters, related to the NSA's use or research of quantum computing technology.

All budget documents and spending reports related to the NSA's activities and expenditures related to quantum computing.

All policies and guidelines related to the NSA's use or research of quantum computing technology, including any regulations or laws governing the use of such technology.

The time frame for this request is the last five years, from January 1, 2018, to the date this request is processed.

I ask that you conduct a search for all responsive records in a manner that is reasonably calculated to locate all records within the scope of this request. Please do not construe my use of the word "any" to be an attempt to limit the scope of this request. Rather, I intend it to be inclusive of all records within the specified time frame that are responsive to this request.

In addition, I am requesting that you provide me with a list of all databases, systems, or other records repositories that were searched, and provide an explanation of the search methods used to identify and locate the records responsive to my request.

Please note that a Glomar response, neither confirming nor denying the existence of records, is not appropriate in this case, as there is already public information indicating that the NSA has been involved in quantum computing research and development. See, e.g., "NSA Research Directorate's Quantum Program," GovernmentCIO Magazine (Feb. 20, 2018).

If any part of my request is denied, please provide a detailed explanation for the denial and cite the specific statutory exemption(s) relied upon. In addition, I request that you provide me with any segregable portions of otherwise exempt material.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

communications.subject: RE: [URL Verdict: Neutral][Non-DoD Source] Freedom of Information Act Request: NSA Quantum Computing Records

If you need to send in supporting documentation via an email attachment after making an electronic submission via our fillable web form, you can submit it to this address:  foianet@nsa.gov<mailto:foianet@nsa.gov> and indicate that it is additional correspondence related to your FOIA web request.

Thank you,
NSA FOIA Requester Service Center

Any ICE FOIA training records or policy guidance referencing “Transgender Law Center v. ICE” or “TLC v. ICE” (NDCal / CA9) “Innovation Law Lab v. ICE” (DNM) “Owen v. ICE” (CDCal) or “Stevens v. ICE” (NDIll). 

Please task a search from May 1, 2022 - the present within the ICE FOIA Office only. 

For context, ICE is subject to declaratory judgments and/or injunctions in each of these FOIA cases. The purpose of this request is to determine whether the agency has informed its FOIA personnel of the judgments and injunctions that are meant to alter your office’s conduct. 

Because federal courts have already declared ICE’s current FOIA processing responses unlawful in each each, we request expedited processing under 6 CFR 5.5(e) and attest that all statements herein are true and correct under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746. Records sought in this request are necessary to prevent the loss of substantial due process rights available to FOIA requestors — namely, the right to receive FOIA determinations and promptly access records within the statutorily defined time periods ICE must obey. 

We make this request on behalf of the #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative of Al Otro Lado.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Salvador Vargas Stewart Death Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The ICE Detainee Death Report regarding Salvador Vargas, 61, who ICE says died April 7, 2023, after being imprisoned at CoreCivic’s Stewart Detention Center in Lumpkin, Georgia, which has housed 10 people for ICE who have died in the past 6 years. https://www.ice.gov/news/releases/noncitizen-ice-custody-passes-away-georgia-hospital

We make this request as a demand for affirmative disclosure under 5 USC 552(a)(2)(D), as well as under 5 USC 552(a)(3) as a demand for prompt access to information. 

Expedited Processing Request 
We make this request for expedited processing pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e), and provide the following statements under penalty of perjury pursuant to 28 USC 1746 in support thereof: 
ICE is under a mandatory obligation, set forth in congressional appropriations language, to post the Death Death Report within 30 days of Mr. Vargas’s death. Detainee deaths have been the subject of widespread media attention culminating in congressional action, including the mandatory reporting requirements ICE itself describes. https://www.ice.gov/detain/detainee-death-reporting. ICE is currently violating that law by allotting itself 90 days instead of 30. The purpose of the Death Report publication requirement is to ensure Congress and the public have information about deaths in custody. Access to timely, complete, and accurate information allows the public to take protective actions and advocate policies that could reduce these deaths. For instance, public outcry over in-custody deaths resulted in Congress ordering the DHS Office of Inspector General to conduct an annual review of ICE and CBP in-custody deaths to determine if any systemic issues contributed to those tragedies and make recommendations about how to address those issues. See https://www.oig.dhs.gov/sites/default/files/assets/2023-02/OIG-23-12-Feb23.pdf. 

As of the date of this request - May 11, 2023 - ICE is in violation of the 30-day Death Report publication requirement. This means the ICE detention system is violating the Anti-Deficiency Act, and ICE leaders are potentially subject to civil and criminal penalties. 

Please grant this request expedited processing and bring ICE into compliance by posting the detainee death report for Mr. Vargas on ICE’s FOIA reading room, or supplying it to the #DetentionKills Transparency Initiative so that we may post it publicly. 

Thank you, 

#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative 
Al Otro Lado

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

(57) Cristian Dimitriscu	Romania		3/7/2023			California

(58) Salvador Vargas	Mexico		4/4/2023	61	Piedmont Regional Columbus 	Georgia 

Expedited Processing Request
Pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e), we hereby request expedited processing of this request, and certify under penalty of perjury that the following is true and correct to the best of our knowledge and understanding: 
The subject of the records at issue - ICE deaths in custody - has been the subject of substantial and widespread media coverage about which there exist significant questions as to the agency’s conduct. Multiple federal courts have held ICE broke the law by failing to timely respond to requests about in-custody deaths, including the courts in Transgender Law Center v. ICE (NDCal/CA9), Innovation Law Lab v. ICE (DNM), and Owen v. ICE (CD Cal). As the folks in charge of IHSC, Smith and Rivera are the IHSC officials with the most (a) institutional knowledge about deaths in ICE custody born of long-term, mandatory reports made to or by them about deaths in custody; and (b) individual responsibility in his respective roles within the agency for preventing preventable deaths. Archiving these officials’ emails for historians and experts to understand their response to 58 deaths in custody, and making these records available to those opposing expansion of the carceral apparatus by ICE in the present moment are essential to preventing another 58 losses of human life in ICE custody in the years to come. 

Pattern and Practice Injunction Advisal 
In August 2021, our project wrote ICE’s FOIA leaders a letter calling attention to an extensive pattern and practice of failing to timely acknowledge FOIA requests, process them for determinations within statutory timeframes, and make records promptly available. We received no response. In January 2023, the US District Court for the Central District of California declared ICE has an unlawful pattern and practice of failing to timely respond to FOIA requests, and entered judgment in favor of families from whom ICE withheld records about deaths in custody for years. We know you are unlikely to acknowledge this request, assign it an individualized tracking number, make a timely determination about whether to grant or deny it, and make these records available promptly, and on an expedited basis. You are unlikely to have read this far until this request is attached to a federal lawsuit. But if that is the necessary means to enforce this request, we respectfully advise you that the Court in Owen v. ICE (CD Cal) has already said “It should not take a lawsuit for an agency to comply with FOIA.” If the agency, after having judgment entered against it for FOIA noncompliance in a lawsuit that should never have been necessary in the first place, cannot bring itself into compliance with FOIA’s timelines, we will invite the Court to do so through an injunction. 

Thank you in advance for your prompt response,  

#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative 
Al Otro Lado

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free

communications.communication:
Dear Ms Lee, 

I am writing to ask for your help with a request under the Virginia State Open Records Law, Va Code sec §2.2-3700 - §2.2-3714.

Previously, you kindly sent us Commitment, Contribution, Distribution, Value and IRR as of June 30, 2022 and September 30, 2022 of your private equity and real estate funds. We were extremely grateful to receive this data, as it is very helpful for our research.  

Do you have more recent records, specifically Commitment, Contribution, Distribution, Value and IRR as of December 31, 2022? This list should include all such partnerships, i.e. private equity, venture capital, distressed debt, mezzanine, fund of funds, real estate, natural resources and private debt investments. Thank you very much for your help with this request.  I understand that I my be charged for the cost of the copes requested and agree to pay these charges.

(58) Salvador Vargas	Mexico		4/4/2023	61	Piedmont Regional Columbus 	Georgia 

Expedited Processing Request
Pursuant to 6 CFR 5.5(e), we hereby request expedited processing of this request, and certify under penalty of perjury that the following is true and correct to the best of our knowledge and understanding: 
The subject of the records at issue - ICE deaths in custody - has been the subject of substantial and widespread media coverage about which there exist significant questions as to the agency’s conduct. Multiple federal courts have held ICE broke the law by failing to timely respond to requests about in-custody deaths, including the courts in Transgender Law Center v. ICE (NDCal/CA9), Innovation Law Lab v. ICE (DNM), and Owen v. ICE (CD Cal). As the Senior Official Performing the Duties of the Acting Director, the prior head of ICE’s Custody Management Division, and the agency’s Acting Director during both the Trump and Biden Administrations, Tae Johnson is the single official with the most (a) institutional knowledge about deaths in ICE custody born of long-term, mandatory reports made to or by him about deaths in custody; and (b) individual responsibility in his respective roles within the agency for preventing preventable deaths. Archiving Johnon’s emails for historians and experts to understand his response to 58 deaths in custody, and making these records available to those opposing expansion of the carceral apparatus by ICE in the present moment are essential to preventing another 58 losses of human life in ICE custody in the years to come. 

Pattern and Practice Injunction Advisal 
In August 2021, our project wrote ICE’s FOIA leaders a letter calling attention to an extensive pattern and practice of failing to timely acknowledge FOIA requests, process them for determinations within statutory timeframes, and make records promptly available. We received no response. In January 2023, the US District Court for the Central District of California declared ICE has an unlawful pattern and practice of failing to timely respond to FOIA requests, and entered judgment in favor of families from whom ICE withheld records about deaths in custody for years. We know you are unlikely to acknowledge this request, assign it an individualized tracking number, make a timely determination about whether to grant or deny it, and make these records available promptly, and on an expedited basis. You are unlikely to have read this far until this request is attached to a federal lawsuit. But if that is the necessary means to enforce this request, we respectfully advise you that the Court in Owen v. ICE (CD Cal) has already said “It should not take a lawsuit for an agency to comply with FOIA.” If the agency, after having judgment entered against it for FOIA noncompliance in a lawsuit that should never have been necessary in the first place, cannot bring itself into compliance with FOIA’s timelines, we will invite the Court to do so through an injunction. 

Thank you in advance for your prompt response,  

Andrew Free
#DetentionKills Transparency Initiative 
Al Otro Lado

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Andrew Free
